item.title: TypeError: Return value of Doctrine\Common\Annotations\AnnotationRegistry::reset() must be an instance of Doctrine\Common\Annotations\void
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
https://www.doctrine-project.org/2017/07/25/php-7.1-requirement-and-composer.html
One question we frequently hear is, "isn't dropping support for a PHP version a BC break"? In a nutshell, no. A BC break happens when there is an incompatible change that your package manager can't handle.
That is harsh. So -- "it's not Doctrine, it's your package manager" -- whatever that may be. This is a classical logical fallacy - "shifting the burden". I don't know the Latin translation, but will look it up... Ignoratio elenchi is one of the fallacies identified by Aristotle in his Organon. In a broader sense he asserted that all fallacies are a form of ignoratio elenchi.[3][4]
Ignoratio Elenchi, according to Aristotle, is a fallacy which arises from "ignorance of the nature of refutation". In order to refute an assertion, Aristotle says we must prove its contradictory; the proof, consequently, of a proposition which stood in any other relation than that to the original, would be an ignoratio elenchi. Since Aristotle, the scope of the fallacy has been extended to include all cases of proving the wrong point "I am required to prove a certain conclusion; I prove, not that, but one which is likely to be mistaken for it; in that lies the fallacy For instance, instead of proving that this person has committed an atrocious fraud, you prove that this fraud he is accused of is atrocious;" The nature of the fallacy, then, consists in substituting for a certain issue another which is more or less closely related to it, and arguing the substituted issue. The fallacy does not take into account whether the arguments do or do not really support the substituted issue, it only calls attention to the fact that they do not constitute a proof of the original one It is a particularly prevalent and subtle fallacy and it assumes a great variety of forms. But whenever it occurs and whatever form it takes, it is brought about by an assumption that leads the person guilty of it to substitute for a definite subject of inquiry another which is in close relation with it.[5] Arthur Ernest Davies, "Fallacies" in A Text-Book of Logic
  1. American interstate speed limits are not the same as those on the German autobahn.
  2. Driving 99 mph on the American interstate is speeding.
  3. The civil code of German interstates should hold true for the world.
  1. I don't use a package manager to install PHP or Doctrine.
  2. I have broken my enterprise web application by installing the newest version of Doctrine, which doesn't support PHP 7.0.
  3. I should be using a package manager.

item.title: The Life of a HTTP Conversation in Drupal: Part 1 of 20
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
First, let us review what a raw HTTP transaction looks like between a client and a server. Next, we will examine how the request is handled and the reponse is generated. HTTP Request message from Client: GET / HTTP/1.1 Host: www.example.com ...Drupal processing on server... HTTP Response message from server: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 22:38:34 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Content-Length: 138 Last-Modified: Wed, 08 Jan 2003 23:11:55 GMT Server: Apache/1.3.3.7 (Unix) (Red-Hat/Linux) ETag: "3f80f-1b6-3e1cb03b" Accept-Ranges: bytes Connection: close An Example Page

Hello World, this is a very simple HTML document.

 The Drupal server processing of requests into responses is composed of several layers, but the component that initiates translation of a request into a response is known as a controller. What exactly is a controller? Is it a PHP or HTML file? A class definition? What is a front controller? What is an action controller? Well, here are a few definitions of what controllers DO gathered from the web:
handles any incoming URL request
deals with user input
receives an input from the users via the View, then processes the user's data with the help of Model and passes the results back to the View
implements a Controller pattern, in which all requests are intercepted by controller and dispatched to individual Action Controllers based on the URL requested (that is routing request from Router).
In Drupal we have: Routing System - decomposes URI endpoint (that part of the URI which comes after the base URL) into parameters to determine which module, controller, and action of that controller should receive the request. Index.php (Front controller) entry point to application HTTP Kernel Abstraction of HTTP messaging layer - both HTTP Request and Response Middleware - ? Caching System - temporary storage tables that store previously used data to speed site up. Drupal has several types of caches or cache bins. When changes are made to config, module code, theming, render arrays, cache must be rebuilt. Theming System - abstraction that determines a particular set of theming hooks, HTML templates, static assets, and so forth Rendering System - process of translating render arrays into HTML

item.title: Intermediate Drupal: Building a Custom Form with #ajax
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In building any custom Drupal form, I would first consider (#2 below) whether the Webform or Views Bulk Operation modules alone would satisfy the use case. Do not waste your time solving problems that have already been solved. If not, would (#3 below) a custom webform handler, validator, custom VBO action, or extension of the Webform module work? Think #2 and #3 instead of #1:
  1. My Custom Module -> My Custom Form -> Drupal Form API -> Drupal.
  2. My Webform -> Webform API -> Drupal Form API -> Drupal.
  3. My Custom Module -> Webform API -> Drupal Form API -> Drupal.
Probably so, but for basic custom Drupal forms one might encounter in an existing codebase (#1), or for a situation where one would need to code a form entirely from the ground up, it can be good to know how to easily spruce these up using the #ajax form property.

item.title: Advanced Drupal: Drupal Core - Performance Settings
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Under the Drupal Admin -> Performance tab, we have several options for improving site performance and bandwidth_optimization. These user-defined settings are stored in important config settings: cache.page.max_age, css.preprocess and system.performance They will control global behaviors such as:
  • max-age of the page cache
  • flags to decide whether to preprocess CSS/JS
  • Aggregation of JS/CSS
In the config table, specifically we are looking for a key called "system.performance". Drupal creates a Config object with this information, using the below interface: Drupal\Core\Config\ConfigFactoryInterface This data will always be stored in the Drupal config tables. Then, in our Config object properties (DB values) we see the associative array containing the following keys, each of which have the user-set value:
  • cache.page.max_age
  • css.preprocess
  • system.performance
Mapping this to the front-end admin UI:
    The admin has two Checkboxes:
  • Aggregate JS files
  • Aggregate CSS files
$form['bandwidth_optimization']['preprocess_js'] js.preprocess, $form['bandwidth_optimization']['preprocess_css'] cs.preprocess, Meanwhile in the attachments processors:
  • ./lib/Drupal/Core/Render/HtmlResponseAttachmentsProcessor.php
  • ./lib/Drupal/Core/Ajax/AjaxResponseAttachmentsProcessor.php
    •  Based on [system.performance][js.preprocess], Drupal decides whether to aggregate the JS.
  • /lib/Drupal/Core/Render/HtmlResponseAttachmentsProcessor.php (has an assetResolver prop - \Drupal\Core\Asset\AssetResolverInterface)
  • /lib/Drupal/Core/Ajax/AjaxResponseAttachmentsProcessor.php

item.title: Freeing up storage with MySQL
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sometimes MySQL takes too much memory. You can drop tables in this situation, but what if the disk is so full MySQL won't connect? In an emergency, you can simply delete the MySQL database from the file system and fix this database later, once your system is functioning normally. sudo ls -alh /var/lib/mysql This should identify memory-consuming databases or tables. rm -rf these directories We then need to add a setting to the mysql config to force recovery. /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf [mysqld_safe] socket = /var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock nice = 0 [mysqld] # # * Basic Settings # innodb_force_recovery=1 user = mysql pid-file = /var/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid socket = /var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock Restart MySQL and your system should be functional again, but will of course want to restore your deleted tables from backup at some point.

item.title: Delete HSTS Settings in Firefox
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
How to Delete HSTS Settings in Firefox:
We will cover two different methods for deleting HSTS settings in Firefox. The first method should work in most cases but we also included a manual option if needed.
Close all open tabs in Firefox. Open the full History window with the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + Shift + H (Cmd + Shift + H on Mac). You must use this window or the sidebar for the below options to be available. Find the site you want to delete the HSTS settings for you can search for the site at the upper right if needed. Right-click the site from the list of items and click Forget About This Site.This should clear the HSTS settings (and other cache data) for that domain. Restart Firefox and visit the site. You should now be able to visit the site over HTTP/broken HTTPS.If these instructions did not work, you can try the following manual method:
Manual Method for Firefox If the above steps do not work, you can try the following method.
Start by locating your Firefox profile folder through your operating systems file explorer. You can find this folder through Firefox by navigating to about:support
Halfway down the page, in the Application Basics section, you will see Profile Folder. Click Open Folder.
Now close Firefox so that the browser does not overwrite any settings we are about to change.
In your Profile folder find and open the file SiteSecurityServiceState.txt. This file contains cached HSTS and HPKP (Key Pinning, a separate HTTPS mechanism) settings for domains you have visited. It may be very disorganized.
Search for the domain you want to clear the HSTS settings for and delete it from the file. Each entry beings with the domain name. Delete the entirety of the entry from the beginning of the desired domain name to the next listed domain. As an alternative, you can rename the existing file from a .txt to a .bak (in order to save the existing file, just in case) and allow Firefox to create an entirely new file on next start up.
Here is an example of a simple HSTS listing:
www.thesslstore.com:HSTS 0 17312 1527362896190,1,0

item.title: MySQL Logs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There are 3 types of MySQL/MariaDB logs:
log_error for the error message log; general_log_file for the general query log file (if enabled by general_log); slow_query_log_file for the slow query log file (if enabled by slow_query_log);
Check the settings and location of above logs by this shell command:
mysql -se "SHOW VARIABLES" | grep -e log_error -e general_log -e slow_query_log
By default the logs are stored in your data dir, so check location by this shell command:
mysql -se "SELECT @@datadir"
To view your error log, you can run:
sudo tail -f $(mysql -Nse "SELECT @@log_error")
If you've general log enabled, to view it, run:
sudo tail -f $(mysql -Nse "SELECT CONCAT(@@datadir, @@general_log_file)")

item.title: Git and SSH on Windows through an HTTP Proxy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sometimes you try to git clone behing a firewall and cannot connect to the git repo. If your workplace requires authentication with a proxy appliance (the horrible, evil Forefront TMG for example) to access the internet, you would receive: ssh: connect to host codeserver.dev.xxx.drush.in port 2222: Operation timed out fatal: Could not read from remote repository. We need to revise two different configurations. SSH 1. First we configure the Windows SSH config. Locate the config which might be in: 2. Add the following lines and save. git config --global http.proxy http://yourusername:yourpass@yourproxy.com:yourproxy.com:8080 git config --global https.proxy http://yourusername:yourpass@yourproxy.com:yourproxy.com:8080 What if your password uses a reserved character such as # or !? In this case the solution is to percent-encode these characters. 3. Percent-encode bad password characters. 4. Re-try to git clone. WINDOWS ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES These are http_proxy and https_proxy. 1. You set them in the: Windows Start -> Control Panel -> System and Security -> System -> Advanced System Settings -> Advanced -> Environment Variables 2. Look for http_proxy and https_proxy and enter for each: https.proxy http://yourusername:yourpass@yourproxy.com:yourproxyport 3. Again, percent-encode bad password characters. 4. Save on Environment Variables screen. 5. Restart any SSH client or terminal application before the changes take effect.

item.title: Git Commands - Undo a Bad Commit Already Pushed
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: UNDO - (git reset) Where 2f4f74e03a8a77440e is the hash of the last known good commit. sudo git reset --hard 2f4f74e03a8a77440e If Git was tracking with pad and pencil, the analogy would be "erasing" so no one can tell you made a mistake. The history looks as though the bad commit never existed. WARNING: git reset is a "DESTRUCTIVE" COMMAND. DO NOT USE IF OTHER PEOPLE ARE SHARING THIS HISTORY. ANTI-COMMIT (git revert) - In contrast to reset which erases your commit from history, revert. REVERT is what you generally want to do when the commit in question is part of a shared history. Revert commits a new revision that brings the code back the original state. If Git was tracking with pad and pencil, the analogy would be "crossing something out". It is uglier but you have an intact historical record. (It is best to assume all commits are part of shared history, hence avoid using reset if possible.)

item.content:encoded: https://www.drupal.org/docs/updating-drupal/updating-drupal-core-via-composer 1. In Git Bash, check for composer : composer -v 2. composer outdated 'drupal/*' 3. check git branch: git branch 4. composer update drupal/core 'drupal/core-*' --with-all-dependencies 5. composer update
